data.title: Unionpedia, the concept map
data.meta_description: Vertebrates comprise all species of animals within the subphylum Vertebrata (chordates with backbones). 850 relations.
data.text:
Table of Contents

850 relations: Abducens nerve, Acanthostega, Acari, Accommodation (eye), Acorn worm, Actinopterygii, Action potential, Adaptive immune system, Adenoviridae, Adhesion, Agnatha, Albert von Kölliker, Albertosaurus, Albinism, Alexander Keyserling, Alexander Kovalevsky, Alfred Romer, Allantois, Allosaurus, Altbib, American bittern, American cliff swallow, American mink, Amniote, Amphibian, Amrum, Anabaena, Analogy, Anatomical terms of location, Anatomy, André Guignard, Androgen, Animal cognition, Animal shelter, Animal testing, Animal welfare, Animals (Scientific Procedures) Act 1986, Ant, Anti-predator adaptation, Antibody, Antifreeze protein, Antioxidant, Antrum, Apicomplexa, Aplomado falcon, Aplysia gill and siphon withdrawal reflex, Appendage, Appendicular skeleton, Aquatic animal, Arbovirus, ... Expand index (800 more) » « Shrink index

Abducens nerve

The abducens nerve is a nerve that controls the movement of the lateral rectus muscle in humans, responsible for outward gaze.

See Vertebrate and Abducens nerve

Acanthostega

Acanthostega (meaning "spiny roof") is an extinct genus of stem-tetrapod, among the first vertebrate animals to have recognizable limbs.

See Vertebrate and Acanthostega

Acari

Acari (or Acarina) are a taxon of arachnids that contains mites and ticks.

See Vertebrate and Acari

Accommodation (eye)

Accommodation is the process by which the vertebrate eye changes optical power to maintain a clear image or focus on an object as its distance varies.

See Vertebrate and Accommodation (eye)

Acorn worm

The acorn worms or Enteropneusta are a hemichordate class of invertebrates consisting of one order of the same name.

See Vertebrate and Acorn worm

Actinopterygii

Actinopterygii, or the ray-finned fishes, constitute a class or subclass of the bony fishes.

See Vertebrate and Actinopterygii

Action potential

In physiology, an action potential occurs when the membrane potential of a specific axon location rapidly rises and falls: this depolarisation then causes adjacent locations to similarly depolarise.

See Vertebrate and Action potential

Adaptive immune system

The adaptive immune system, also known as the acquired immune system or, more rarely, as the specific immune system, is a subsystem of the overall immune system that is composed of highly specialized, systemic cells and processes that eliminate pathogens or prevent their growth.

See Vertebrate and Adaptive immune system

Adenoviridae

Adenoviruses (members of the family Adenoviridae) are medium-sized (90–100 nm), nonenveloped (without an outer lipid bilayer) viruses with an icosahedral nucleocapsid containing a double stranded DNA genome.

See Vertebrate and Adenoviridae

Adhesion

Adhesion is the tendency of dissimilar particles or surfaces to cling to one another (cohesion refers to the tendency of similar or identical particles/surfaces to cling to one another).

See Vertebrate and Adhesion

Agnatha

Agnatha (Greek, "no jaws") is a superclass of jawless fish in the phylum Chordata, subphylum Vertebrata, consisting of both present (cyclostomes) and extinct (conodonts and ostracoderms) species.

See Vertebrate and Agnatha

Albert von Kölliker

Albert von Kölliker (born Rudolf Albert Kölliker; 6 July 18172 November 1905) was a Swiss anatomist, physiologist, and histologist.

See Vertebrate and Albert von Kölliker

Albertosaurus

Albertosaurus (meaning "Alberta lizard") is a genus of tyrannosaurid theropod dinosaurs that lived in western North America during the Late Cretaceous Period, about 70 million years ago.

See Vertebrate and Albertosaurus

Albinism

Albinism in humans is a congenital disorder characterized by the complete or partial absence of pigment in the skin, hair and eyes.

See Vertebrate and Albinism

Alexander Keyserling

Count Alexander Friedrich Michael Lebrecht Nikolaus Arthur von Keyserling (15 August 1815 in Kabile Parish – 8 May 1891 in Raikküla) was a Baltic German geologist and paleontologist from the Keyserlingk family of Baltic German nobility.

See Vertebrate and Alexander Keyserling

Alexander Kovalevsky

Alexander Onufrievich Kovalevsky (Aleksander Kowalewski, 7 November 1840 in Vārkava, Vitebsk Governorate (present-day Vārkava Municipality, Latvia) – 1901), also written Alexander Kowalevsky, was a Russian embryologist of Polish descent, who studied medicine at the University of Heidelberg and became professor at St Petersburg.

See Vertebrate and Alexander Kovalevsky

Alfred Romer

Alfred Sherwood Romer (December 28, 1894 – November 5, 1973) was an American paleontologist and biologist and a specialist in vertebrate evolution.

See Vertebrate and Alfred Romer

Allantois

The allantois (plural allantoides or allantoises) is a hollow sac-like structure filled with clear fluid that forms part of a developing amniote's conceptus (which consists of all embryonic and extra-embryonic tissues).

See Vertebrate and Allantois

Allosaurus

Allosaurus is a genus of carnivorous theropod dinosaur that lived 155 to 150 million years ago during the late Jurassic period (Kimmeridgian to early TithonianTurner, C.E. and Peterson, F., (1999). "Biostratigraphy of dinosaurs in the Upper Jurassic Morrison Formation of the Western Interior, U.S.A." Pp. 77–114 in Gillette, D.D. (ed.), Vertebrate Paleontology in Utah. Utah Geological Survey Miscellaneous Publication 99-1.). The name "Allosaurus" means "different lizard" alluding to its unique concave vertebrae (at the time of its discovery).

See Vertebrate and Allosaurus

Altbib

Bibliography on Alternatives to the Use of Live Vertebrates in Biomedical Research and Testing, or Altbib, is a bibliography available online to assist in identifying methods and procedures helpful in supporting the development, testing, application, and validation of alternatives to the use of vertebrates in biomedical research and toxicology testing.

See Vertebrate and Altbib

American bittern

The American bittern (Botaurus lentiginosus) is a species of wading bird in the heron family of the Pelican order of bird.

See Vertebrate and American bittern

American cliff swallow

The American cliff swallow (Petrochelidon pyrrhonota) is a member of the passerine bird family Hirundinidae consisting of both swallow and martin species.

See Vertebrate and American cliff swallow

American mink

The American mink (Neovison vison) is a semiaquatic species of mustelid native to North America, though human intervention has expanded its range to many parts of Europe and South America.

See Vertebrate and American mink

Amniote

Amniotes (from Greek ἀμνίον amnion, "membrane surrounding the fetus", earlier "bowl in which the blood of sacrificed animals was caught", from ἀμνός amnos, "lamb") are a clade of tetrapod vertebrates comprising the reptiles, birds, and mammals.

See Vertebrate and Amniote

Amphibian

Amphibians are ectothermic, tetrapod vertebrates of the class Amphibia.

See Vertebrate and Amphibian

Amrum

Amrum (''Öömrang'' North Frisian: Oomram) is one of the North Frisian Islands on the German North Sea coast, south of Sylt and west of Föhr.

See Vertebrate and Amrum

Anabaena

Anabaena is a genus of filamentous cyanobacteria that exist as plankton.

See Vertebrate and Anabaena

Analogy

Analogy (from Greek ἀναλογία, analogia, "proportion", from ana- "upon, according to" + logos "ratio") is a cognitive process of transferring information or meaning from a particular subject (the analog, or source) to another (the target), or a linguistic expression corresponding to such a process.

See Vertebrate and Analogy

Anatomical terms of location

Standard anatomical terms of location deal unambiguously with the anatomy of animals, including humans.

See Vertebrate and Anatomical terms of location

Anatomy

Anatomy (Greek anatomē, “dissection”) is the branch of biology concerned with the study of the structure of organisms and their parts.

See Vertebrate and Anatomy

André Guignard

André Guignard is a Swiss engineer initially educated as a watchmaker.

See Vertebrate and André Guignard

Androgen

An androgen (from Greek andr-, the stem of the word meaning "man") is any natural or synthetic steroid hormone which regulates the development and maintenance of male characteristics in vertebrates by binding to androgen receptors.

See Vertebrate and Androgen

Animal cognition

Animal cognition describes the mental capacities of non-human animals and the study of those capacities.

See Vertebrate and Animal cognition

Animal shelter

An animal shelter or pound is a place where stray, lost, abandoned or surrendered animals, mostly dogs and cats, and sometimes sick or wounded wildlife are kept and rehabilitated.

See Vertebrate and Animal shelter

Animal testing

Animal testing, also known as animal experimentation, animal research and in vivo testing, is the use of non-human animals in experiments that seek to control the variables that affect the behavior or biological system under study.

See Vertebrate and Animal testing

Animal welfare

Animal welfare is the well-being of animals.

See Vertebrate and Animal welfare

Animals (Scientific Procedures) Act 1986

The Animals (Scientific Procedures) Act 1986, sometimes referred to as ASPA, is an Act of the Parliament of the United Kingdom (1986 c. 14) passed in 1986, which regulates the use of animals used for research in the UK.

See Vertebrate and Animals (Scientific Procedures) Act 1986

Ant

Ants are eusocial insects of the family Formicidae and, along with the related wasps and bees, belong to the order Hymenoptera.

See Vertebrate and Ant

Anti-predator adaptation

Anti-predator adaptations are mechanisms developed through evolution that assist prey organisms in their constant struggle against predators.

See Vertebrate and Anti-predator adaptation

Antibody

An antibody (Ab), also known as an immunoglobulin (Ig), is a large, Y-shaped protein produced mainly by plasma cells that is used by the immune system to neutralize pathogens such as pathogenic bacteria and viruses.

See Vertebrate and Antibody

Antifreeze protein

Antifreeze proteins (AFPs) or ice structuring proteins (ISPs) refer to a class of polypeptides produced by certain vertebrates, plants, fungi and bacteria that permit their survival in subzero environments.

See Vertebrate and Antifreeze protein

Antioxidant

Antioxidants are molecules that inhibit the oxidation of other molecules.

See Vertebrate and Antioxidant

Antrum

In biology, antrum is a general term for a cavity or chamber, which may have specific meaning in reference to certain organs or sites in the body.

See Vertebrate and Antrum

Apicomplexa

The Apicomplexa (also called Apicomplexia) are a large phylum of parasitic alveolates.

See Vertebrate and Apicomplexa

Aplomado falcon

The aplomado falcon (Falco femoralis) is a medium-sized falcon of the Americas.

See Vertebrate and Aplomado falcon

Aplysia gill and siphon withdrawal reflex

The Aplysia gill and siphon withdrawal reflex (GSWR) is an involuntary, defensive reflex of the sea hare Aplysia californica, a large shell-less sea snail or sea slug.

See Vertebrate and Aplysia gill and siphon withdrawal reflex

Appendage

In invertebrate biology, an appendage (or outgrowth) is an external body part, or natural prolongation, that protrudes from an organism's body (in vertebrate biology, an example would be a vertebrate's limbs).

See Vertebrate and Appendage

Appendicular skeleton

The appendicular skeleton is the portion of the skeleton of vertebrates consisting of the bones that support the appendages.

See Vertebrate and Appendicular skeleton

Aquatic animal

A aquatic animal is an animal, either vertebrate or invertebrate, which lives in the water for most or all of its lifetime.

See Vertebrate and Aquatic animal

Arbovirus

Arbovirus is an informal name used to refer to any viruses that are transmitted by arthropod vectors.

See Vertebrate and Arbovirus

Aristotle

Aristotle (Ἀριστοτέλης Aristotélēs,; 384–322 BC) was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in the city of Stagira, Chalkidiki, in the north of Classical Greece.

See Vertebrate and Aristotle

Army ant

The name army ant (or legionary ant or marabunta) is applied to over 200 ant species, in different lineages, due to their aggressive predatory foraging groups, known as "raids", in which huge numbers of ants forage simultaneously over a certain area.

See Vertebrate and Army ant

Articular bone

The articular bone is part of the lower jaw of most vertebrates, including most jawed fish, amphibians, birds and various kinds of reptiles, as well as Stem-mammal.

See Vertebrate and Articular bone

Ascidiacea

Ascidiacea (commonly known as the ascidians or sea squirts) is a paraphyletic class in the subphylum Tunicata of sac-like marine invertebrate filter feeders.

See Vertebrate and Ascidiacea

Asexual reproduction

Asexual reproduction is a type of reproduction by which offspring arise from a single organism, and inherit the genes of that parent only; it does not involve the fusion of gametes, and almost never changes the number of chromosomes.

See Vertebrate and Asexual reproduction

Asian koel

The Asian koel (Eudynamys scolopaceus) is a member of the cuckoo order of birds, the Cuculiformes.

See Vertebrate and Asian koel

Asinara

Asinara is an Italian island of in area.

See Vertebrate and Asinara

Aspidogastrea

The Aspidogastrea (Ancient Greek: ἀσπίς aspis “shield”, γαστήρ gaster “stomach/pouch”) is a small group of flukes comprising about 80 species.

See Vertebrate and Aspidogastrea

Assortative mating

Assortative mating is a mating pattern and a form of sexual selection in which individuals with similar phenotypes mate with one another more frequently than would be expected under a random mating pattern.

See Vertebrate and Assortative mating

Atlantic Forest

The Atlantic Forest (Mata Atlântica) is a South American forest that extends along the Atlantic coast of Brazil from Rio Grande do Norte state in the north to Rio Grande do Sul state in the south, and inland as far as Paraguay and the Misiones Province of Argentina, where the region is known as Selva Misionera.

See Vertebrate and Atlantic Forest

Atlantic horseshoe crab

The Atlantic horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus), also known as the American horseshoe crab, is a species of marine and brackish chelicerate arthropod.

See Vertebrate and Atlantic horseshoe crab

Auditory cortex

The primary auditory cortex is the part of the temporal lobe that processes auditory information in humans and other vertebrates.

See Vertebrate and Auditory cortex

Auditory system

The auditory system is the sensory system for the sense of hearing.

See Vertebrate and Auditory system

Australian Museum

The Australian Museum is the oldest museum in Australia, with an international reputation in the fields of natural history and anthropology.

See Vertebrate and Australian Museum

Automatic gain control

Automatic gain control (AGC), also called automatic volume control (AVC), is a closed-loop feedback regulating circuit in an amplifier or chain of amplifiers, the purpose of which is to maintain a suitable signal amplitude at its output, despite variation of the signal amplitude at the input.

See Vertebrate and Automatic gain control

Awareness

Awareness is the ability to directly know and perceive, to feel, or to be cognizant of events.

See Vertebrate and Awareness

Axial skeleton

The axial skeleton is the part of the skeleton that consists of the bones of the head and trunk of a vertebrate.

See Vertebrate and Axial skeleton

Émile Blanchard

Charles Émile Blanchard (6 March 1819 – 11 February 1900) was a French zoologist and entomologist.

See Vertebrate and Émile Blanchard

Bacteriorhodopsin

Bacteriorhodopsin is a protein used by Archaea, most notably by Halobacteria, a class of the Euryarchaeota.

See Vertebrate and Bacteriorhodopsin

Baculoviridae

Baculoviridae is a family of viruses.

See Vertebrate and Baculoviridae

Balanoglossus

Balanoglossus is an ocean-dwelling acorn worm (Enteropneusta) genus of great zoological interest because, being a Hemichordate, it is an "evolutionary link" between invertebrates and vertebrates.

See Vertebrate and Balanoglossus

Bald-faced hornet

Dolichovespula maculata is a eusocial wasp of the cosmopolitan family Vespidae.

See Vertebrate and Bald-faced hornet

Band-rumped storm petrel

The band-rumped storm petrel, Madeiran storm petrel, or Harcourt's storm petrel (Oceanodroma castro) is of the storm petrel family Hydrobatidae.

See Vertebrate and Band-rumped storm petrel

Barbary dove

The Barbary dove, ringed turtle dove, ringneck dove, ring-necked turtle dove, or ring dove (Streptopelia risoria) is a domestic member of the dove family (Columbidae).

See Vertebrate and Barbary dove

Bartonella

Bartonella is a genus of Gram-negative bacteria.

See Vertebrate and Bartonella

Basal ganglia

The basal ganglia (or basal nuclei) is a group of subcortical nuclei, of varied origin, in the brains of vertebrates including humans, which are situated at the base of the forebrain.

See Vertebrate and Basal ganglia

Bearded saki

The bearded sakis, or cuxiús are five species of New World monkeys, classified in the genus Chiropotes.

See Vertebrate and Bearded saki

Bee learning and communication

Honey bees are sensitive to odors (including pheromones), tastes, and colors, including ultraviolet.

See Vertebrate and Bee learning and communication

Bengal monitor

The Bengal monitor (Varanus bengalensis) or common Indian monitor, is a monitor lizard found widely distributed over the Indian Subcontinent, as well as parts of Southeast Asia and West Asia.

See Vertebrate and Bengal monitor

Bermuda rock skink

The Bermuda skink or rock lizard (Plestiodon longirostris, formerly Eumeces longirostrisBrandley M.C., Schmitz A., Reeder T.W. (2005). "Partitioned Bayesian analyses, partition choice, and the phylogenetic relationships of scincid lizards." Systematic Biology 54 (3): 373–390. Smith, H.M. (2005). "Plestiodon: a replacement name for most members of the genus Eumeces in North America." Journal of Kansas Herpetology 14: 15–16.) is a critically endangered species and the only endemic land-living vertebrate of Bermuda.

See Vertebrate and Bermuda rock skink

Big-eared hopping mouse

The big-eared hopping mouse (Notomys macrotis) is an extinct species of mouse, which lived in the Moore River area of south-western Australia.

See Vertebrate and Big-eared hopping mouse

Bile

Bile or gall is a dark green to yellowish brown fluid, produced by the liver of most vertebrates, that aids the digestion of lipids in the small intestine.

See Vertebrate and Bile

Bile duct

A bile duct is any of a number of long tube-like structures that carry bile, and is present in most vertebrates.

See Vertebrate and Bile duct

Bilirubin

Bilirubin is a yellow compound that occurs in the normal catabolic pathway that breaks down heme in vertebrates.

See Vertebrate and Bilirubin

Biochemistry

Biochemistry, sometimes called biological chemistry, is the study of chemical processes within and relating to living organisms.

See Vertebrate and Biochemistry

Biodiversity

Biodiversity, a portmanteau of biological (life) and diversity, generally refers to the variety and variability of life on Earth.

See Vertebrate and Biodiversity

Biodiversity of New Caledonia

The biodiversity of New Caledonia is of exceptional biological and paleoecological interest.

See Vertebrate and Biodiversity of New Caledonia

Biodiversity of New Zealand

The biodiversity of New Zealand, a large island nation located in the southwestern Pacific Ocean, is varied and distinctive accumulated over many millions of years as lineages evolved in the local circumstances.

See Vertebrate and Biodiversity of New Zealand

Bioinorganic chemistry

Bioinorganic chemistry is a field that examines the role of metals in biology.

See Vertebrate and Bioinorganic chemistry

Bioluminescence

Bioluminescence is the production and emission of light by a living organism.

See Vertebrate and Bioluminescence

Biomineralization

Biomineralization is the process by which living organisms produce minerals, often to harden or stiffen existing tissues.

See Vertebrate and Biomineralization

Biosphere 2

Biosphere 2 is an American Earth system science research facility located in Oracle, Arizona.

See Vertebrate and Biosphere 2

Bird

Birds, also known as Aves, are a group of endothermic vertebrates, characterised by feathers, toothless beaked jaws, the laying of hard-shelled eggs, a high metabolic rate, a four-chambered heart, and a strong yet lightweight skeleton.

See Vertebrate and Bird

Bird of prey

A bird of prey, predatory bird, or raptor is any of several species of bird that hunts and feeds on rodents and other animals.

See Vertebrate and Bird of prey

Björn Kurtén

Björn Olof Lennartson Kurtén (19 November 1924 – 28 December 1988) was a Finnish vertebrate paleontologist, belonging to the Swedish-speaking minority of his country.

See Vertebrate and Björn Kurtén

Black-tufted marmoset

The black-tufted marmoset (Callithrix penicillata), also known as Mico-estrela in Portuguese, is a species of New World monkey that lives primarily in the Neo-tropical gallery forests of the Brazilian Central Plateau.

See Vertebrate and Black-tufted marmoset

Blanding's turtle

Blanding's turtle (Emys blandingii or Emydoidea blandingii) is a semi-aquatic turtle of the family Emydidae.

See Vertebrate and Blanding's turtle

Blastula

The blastula (from Greek βλαστός (blastos), meaning "sprout") is a hollow sphere of cells, referred to as blastomeres, surrounding an inner fluid-filled cavity called the blastocoele formed during an early stage of embryonic development in animals.

See Vertebrate and Blastula

Blood

Blood is a body fluid in humans and other animals that delivers necessary substances such as nutrients and oxygen to the cells and transports metabolic waste products away from those same cells.

See Vertebrate and Blood

Blue-faced malkoha

The blue-faced malkoha (Phaenicophaeus viridirostris) is a member of the cuckoo order of birds, the Cuculiformes, which also includes the roadrunners, the anis, and the hoatzin.

See Vertebrate and Blue-faced malkoha

Body water

In physiology, body water is the water content of an animal body that is contained in the tissues, the blood, the bones and elsewhere.

See Vertebrate and Body water

Bone

A bone is a rigid organ that constitutes part of the vertebrate skeleton.

See Vertebrate and Bone

Bonobo

The bonobo (Pan paniscus), formerly called the pygmy chimpanzee and less often, the dwarf or gracile chimpanzee, is an endangered great ape and one of the two species making up the genus Pan; the other is Pan troglodytes, or the common chimpanzee.

See Vertebrate and Bonobo

Book lung

A book lung is a type of respiration organ used for atmospheric gas exchange that is found in many arachnids, such as scorpions and spiders.

See Vertebrate and Book lung

Borrelia burgdorferi

Borrelia burgdorferi is a bacterial species of the spirochete class of the genus Borrelia.

See Vertebrate and Borrelia burgdorferi

Botulism

Botulism is a rare and potentially fatal illness caused by a toxin produced by the bacterium Clostridium botulinum.

See Vertebrate and Botulism

Bowfin

Bowfin (Amia calva) are basal bony fishes related to gars in the infraclass Holostei.

See Vertebrate and Bowfin

Brain

The brain is an organ that serves as the center of the nervous system in all vertebrate and most invertebrate animals.

See Vertebrate and Brain

Brain tumor

A brain tumor occurs when abnormal cells form within the brain.

See Vertebrate and Brain tumor

Brugmansia

Brugmansia is a genus of seven species of flowering plants in the family Solanaceae.

See Vertebrate and Brugmansia

Bruhathkayosaurus

Bruhathkayosaurus (meaning "huge bodied lizard") is a dinosaur, with remains found in India, claimed by some researchers to have been the largest dinosaur that ever lived.

See Vertebrate and Bruhathkayosaurus

Burrowing owl

The burrowing owl (Athene cunicularia) is a small, long-legged owl found throughout open landscapes of North and South America.

See Vertebrate and Burrowing owl

Bustard

Bustards, including floricans and korhaans, are large, terrestrial birds living mainly in dry grassland areas and on the steppes of the Old World.

See Vertebrate and Bustard

Cacomistle

The cacomistle, Bassariscus sumichrasti, is a nocturnal, arboreal and omnivorous member of the carnivoran family Procyonidae.

See Vertebrate and Cacomistle

Calcium in biology

Calcium ions (Ca2+) play a vital role in the physiology and biochemistry of organisms and the cell.

See Vertebrate and Calcium in biology

Caliciviridae

The Caliciviridae are a family of viruses, members of Class IV of the Baltimore scheme.

See Vertebrate and Caliciviridae

Camiguin

Camiguin (Lalawigan sa Camiguin) is an island province in the Philippines located in the Bohol Sea, about off the northern coast of Mindanao.

See Vertebrate and Camiguin

Cape York Peninsula

Cape York Peninsula is a large remote peninsula located in Far North Queensland, Australia.

See Vertebrate and Cape York Peninsula

Capuchin monkey

The capuchin monkeys are New World monkeys of the subfamily Cebinae.

See Vertebrate and Capuchin monkey

Carbon dioxide

Carbon dioxide (chemical formula) is a colorless gas with a density about 60% higher than that of dry air.

See Vertebrate and Carbon dioxide

Carboniferous

The Carboniferous is a geologic period and system that spans 60 million years from the end of the Devonian Period million years ago (Mya), to the beginning of the Permian Period, Mya.

See Vertebrate and Carboniferous

Carl Gustav Carus

Carl Gustav Carus (3 January 1789 – 28 July 1869) was a German physiologist and painter, born in Leipzig, who played various roles during the Romantic era.

See Vertebrate and Carl Gustav Carus

Carl Jakob Sundevall

Carl Jakob Sundevall (22 October 1801, Högestad – 2 February 1875) was a Swedish zoologist.

See Vertebrate and Carl Jakob Sundevall

Carnivore

A carnivore, meaning "meat eater" (Latin, caro, genitive carnis, meaning "meat" or "flesh" and vorare meaning "to devour"), is an organism that derives its energy and nutrient requirements from a diet consisting mainly or exclusively of animal tissue, whether through predation or scavenging.

See Vertebrate and Carnivore

Carpal bones

The carpal bones are the eight small bones that make up the wrist (or carpus) that connects the hand to the forearm.

See Vertebrate and Carpal bones

Cassowary

Cassowaries, genus Casuarius, are ratites (flightless birds without a keel on their sternum bone) that are native to the tropical forests of New Guinea (Papua New Guinea and Indonesia), nearby islands, and northeastern Australia.

See Vertebrate and Cassowary

Catch and release

Catch and release is a practice within recreational fishing intended as a technique of conservation.

See Vertebrate and Catch and release

Catfish

Catfish (or catfishes; order Siluriformes or Nematognathi) are a diverse group of ray-finned fish.

See Vertebrate and Catfish

Cattle egret

The cattle egret (Bubulcus ibis) is a cosmopolitan species of heron (family Ardeidae) found in the tropics, subtropics and warm temperate zones.

See Vertebrate and Cattle egret

Caudal artery

The Caudal artery is the portion of the dorsal aorta of a vertebrate that passes into the tail.

See Vertebrate and Caudal artery

Caveolin

In molecular biology Caveolins are a family of integral membrane proteins that are the principal components of caveolae membranes and involved in receptor-independent endocytosis.

See Vertebrate and Caveolin

Cell growth

The term cell growth is used in the contexts of biological cell development and cell division (reproduction).

See Vertebrate and Cell growth

Cell junction

A cell junction (or intercellular bridge) is a type of structure that exists within the tissue of some multicellular organisms, such as animals.

See Vertebrate and Cell junction

Cell nucleus

In cell biology, the nucleus (pl. nuclei; from Latin nucleus or nuculeus, meaning kernel or seed) is a membrane-enclosed organelle found in eukaryotic cells.

See Vertebrate and Cell nucleus

Centaurea

Centaurea is a genus of between 350 and 600 species of herbaceous thistle-like flowering plants in the family Asteraceae.

See Vertebrate and Centaurea

Central nervous system

The central nervous system (CNS) is the part of the nervous system consisting of the brain and spinal cord.

See Vertebrate and Central nervous system

Central sulcus

The central sulcus is a sulcus, or fold, in the cerebral cortex in the brains of vertebrates.

See Vertebrate and Central sulcus

Cephalization

Cephalization is an evolutionary trend in which, over many generations, the mouth, sense organs, and nerve ganglia become concentrated at the front end of an animal, producing a head region.

See Vertebrate and Cephalization

Cerebellar vermis

The cerebellar vermis (Latin for worm) is located in the medial, cortico-nuclear zone of the cerebellum, which resides in the posterior fossa of the cranium.

See Vertebrate and Cerebellar vermis

Cerebellum

The cerebellum (Latin for "little brain") is a major feature of the hindbrain of all vertebrates.

See Vertebrate and Cerebellum

Cerebral cortex

The cerebral cortex is the largest region of the cerebrum in the mammalian brain and plays a key role in memory, attention, perception, cognition, awareness, thought, language, and consciousness.

See Vertebrate and Cerebral cortex

Cerebral hemisphere

The vertebrate cerebrum (brain) is formed by two cerebral hemispheres that are separated by a groove, the longitudinal fissure.

See Vertebrate and Cerebral hemisphere

Cervical spine disorder

Cervical spine disorders are illnesses that affect the cervical spine, which is made up of the upper first seven vertebrae, encasing and shielding the spinal cord.

See Vertebrate and Cervical spine disorder

Cervical vertebrae

In vertebrates, cervical vertebrae (singular: vertebra) are the vertebrae of the neck, immediately below the skull.

See Vertebrate and Cervical vertebrae

Chaetognatha

Chaetognatha, meaning bristle-jaws, and commonly known as arrow worms, is a phylum of predatory marine worms which are a major component of plankton worldwide.

See Vertebrate and Chaetognatha

Channelrhodopsin

Channelrhodopsins are a subfamily of retinylidene proteins (rhodopsins) that function as light-gated ion channels.

See Vertebrate and Channelrhodopsin

Channichthyidae

Eosinophil

Eosinophils sometimes called eosinophiles or, less commonly, acidophils, are a variety of white blood cells and one of the immune system components responsible for combating multicellular parasites and certain infections in vertebrates. Along with mast cells and basophils, they also control mechanisms associated with allergy and asthma. They are granulocytes that develop during hematopoiesis in the bone marrow before migrating into blood, after which they are terminally differentiated and do not multiply. These cells are eosinophilic or "acid-loving" due to their large acidophilic cytoplasmic granules, which show their affinity for acids by their affinity to coal tar dyes: Normally transparent, it is this affinity that causes them to appear brick-red after staining with eosin, a red dye, using the Romanowsky method. The staining is concentrated in small granules within the cellular cytoplasm, which contain many chemical mediators, such as eosinophil peroxidase, ribonuclease (RNase), deoxyribonucleases (DNase), lipase, plasminogen, and major basic protein. These mediators are released by a process called degranulation following activation of the eosinophil, and are toxic to both parasite and host tissues. In normal individuals, eosinophils make up about 1–3% of white blood cells, and are about 12–17 micrometres in size with bilobed nuclei. While they are released into the bloodstream as neutrophils are, eosinophils reside in tissue They are found in the medulla and the junction between the cortex and medulla of the thymus, and, in the lower gastrointestinal tract, ovary, uterus, spleen, and lymph nodes, but not in the lung, skin, esophagus, or some other internal organs under normal conditions. The presence of eosinophils in these latter organs is associated with disease. For instance, patients with eosinophilic asthma have high levels of eosinophils that lead to inflammation and tissue damage, making it more difficult for patients to breathe. Eosinophils persist in the circulation for 8–12 hours, and can survive in tissue for an additional 8–12 days in the absence of stimulation. Pioneering work in the 1980s elucidated that eosinophils were unique granulocytes, having the capacity to survive for extended periods of time after their maturation as demonstrated by ex-vivo culture experiments.

See Vertebrate and Eosinophil
